title: elouz
author: elouz
content: Hello , we're  all seeing the rising fees when it comes for crypto payment , as an example : "buysellvouchers" got it's fees from 0.4% to 0.5% when buying , and if we include the network fees too, it starts to add up , so i'm here to ask about your opinion on the best crypto to use to get less fees and be optimal , is it bitcoin ? LTC, or simply usdt ? especially when trading big amounts ( i'm pointing the treatment speed and value ), thanks for your replies.

comments.author: Zaguru12
comments.body: Quote from: elouz on July 14, 2023, 04:02:26 PMis it bitcoin ? LTC, or simply usdt ? especially when trading big amounts ( i'm pointing the treatment speed and value ), thanks for your replies.If we talk about the fastest in transaction then the likes of XRP, litecoin, Solana and Ethereum are ahead of bitcoin. But in value and safety I wound definitely go for bitcoin. Bitcoin is the Most trusted coin on the Blockchain. The other Altcoins do not have the liquidity and also the stability of bitcoin. The only coin stable compare to bitcoin is the usdt and even it has its disadvantages. Usdt isn’t fully backed by a the dollar and just like the Usdc it can also be depegged which would result in its dumping. Yes the bitcoin transaction fee is sometimes high due to mempool congestion, but with the introduction of the lightning network this issue can be reduced. So for large transactions I would advice the use of bitcoin because it is secure and also has value

LTC, or simply usdt ? especially when trading big amounts ( i'm pointing the treatment speed and value ), thanks for your replies.The fees are fairly normal this days, not as high as they were some weeks ago when the fees were ridiculous and discouraged many people from transacting with bitcoins. I made a transaction this morning, and as usual I always check the mempool before making such transactions. The fees for low, medium and high priority were as low as 6sat/vB. If you are looking to make cheap transactions, do them at a time when you know that the mempool will not be crowded, like late in the night or the early hours of the morning.

comments.author: Cryptomultiplier
comments.body: The current fees no matter how much it has risen to, shouldn't deter you from trading, especially if you are invested in BTC and understand how bullish and bearish market seasons affect your profit more than charges would. BTC is assuredly better if you don't want to be too bothered about moving your coins, as is the case of many alt traders during times when the news about dumping is rampant.

comments.author: Unbunplease
comments.body: The issue of commissions is one of the main issues affecting the decision on whether to keep money in cryptocurrency. Recently, commissions have been as high as $50 or more per transaction (when the hype starts). There are also hidden fees when using bridges between blockchains.

comments.author: boyptc
comments.body: The fees differ on what has been set by the exchange. Always look for the makers and takers fee so that you can see on how much you've been charged for the trades that you do.But does this still matter when you trade? Because usually the fees aren't that much and you only have to be worried of it if it's slashing a huge chunk to the entire amount that you've made.

comments.author: dothebeats
comments.body: It's XRP for me, hands-down. I haven't had any problems in transferring coins from one platform to another using this coin, and the fees are also minimal when it's the coin you're using. If you're keeping it in your wallet however, there's no other way around it but to use bitcoin as is and just shoulder the fees. But from one exchange to another, just use XRP and you'll be fine. There are other coins out there that doesn't charge much, though you will have to check its network activities and that might take some work, but you'll save a couple of dollars.

Looking at the Bitcoin mempool congestion a few months ago due to the buildup of transactions caused by Ordinal NFT. Fees are very expensive and the confirmation time is very long, I need 10x the usual fee with a confirmation time of more than 24 hours.Quote from: Unbunplease on July 14, 2023, 08:39:47 PM-snip- There are also hidden fees when using bridges between blockchains.Bridges between blockchains are more expensive and the average usage cost is also the same for each bridge platform. It also depends on the amount of gas fee at that time. As happened in the ETH network, sometimes the gas fee rises, and the sending fee will be more expensive.

You have to pay such on-chain transaction fees and after that, when you trade, you will have to pay trading fee on their platforms.You can choose times when the USA., European countries are in sleep times to have cheaper transaction fees.You can pick altcoins to have cheaper transaction fee than Bitcoin but don't pick Ethereum which always has very expensive on-chain transaction fee.If you decide to use altcoins, you have to accept risk that those altcoin networks are more easily attacked because they have lower network hashrates and their networks are more centralized.Use https://bitinfocharts.com/ to get comparisons of transaction fees among top altcoins.

comments.author: FinneysTrueVision
comments.body: USDT is available on over a dozen blockchains. The cheapest of these and most widely accepted is probably the Tron version. From the options listed on buysellvouchers.com TRC-20 Tether is the cheapest option. My understanding is that the gift cards sold on this site are not coming from authorized resellers which means there is a possibility of getting scammed. You could end up with a gift card that was bought with a stolen credit card and then your account might get suspended by the merchant when you try to use it. There are better options for buying gift cards like Bitrefill and Coincards which accept Lightning Network payments so you can pay with BTC with very minimal fees.

Don't bother trying any tokens on the Ethereum network since the network fee itself is highly insane compared to other blockchain.
